The Terminology page displays a search bar that allows you to search for common terminology for Android Development
The Website page displays the URL of a list of websites for Android Development
Name: Ka Yee Jason Fung
Program: Computer Programming and Analysis Co-op
I study at Seneca College. Below is the logo.
Below are the links to 12 websites that are good for learning Android Development.
Below is a search box for looking up some common terminologies in Android
Search:
adb
emulator
android
screenshot2
gradle
pm
lint
project
panel
toolbar
statusbar
branch
intellisense
module
init
commit
push
add
pull
clone
adb stands for Android Debug Bridge. It is a command used to check whether my computer and my Android device are connected.
emulator is a command used to launch the emulator.
android is a command used to launch the Android SDK Manager.
screenshot2 is a command used to capture a screenshot of my application.
gradle is a command used to run gradle and check the version number of gradle installed.
pm stands for package manager. It is a command used to perform actions on the application packages installed on your Android device.
lint is a command that checks for potential bugs in the your gradle project.
project is a workspace where you develop your mobile application.
panel is a rectangular box that can have multiple panes (i.e. Preview, Gradle, Maven Projects, etc).
toolbar is located near the top of Android Studio display below the menu bar.
statusbar tells you which components of Android Studio are currently running and their current status.
branch allows you to create, list, rename and delete branches. A branch is an independent line of development for your project.
intellisense is an autocompletion feature of many SDKs or IDEs that suggests a list of possible codes as you type your codes.
module is a component of my app that I can build, test and debug independently.
init means to initilize a directory as a Git repository for my project.
commit means to save all the changes that I have made to my project into my Git repository.
push means to transfer the last commit to a remote repository (ie. Github).
add means to add a change to my Git repository.
pull means to pull from a remote repository and try to merge into the current branch.
clone means to clone an existing repository from elsewhere (ie. Github).
